message: has anyone here used SproutCore?
Never used SproutCore
I have
@johnbellone I know where you can get one. Good luck!
I've used handlebars and the context part was the toughest for me to *get*
it's a little weird hearing Yehuda talk about something other than Rails
I’ve used Sproutcore 0.9 and 1.0, and didn’t really like the approach they used. SC 2.x has a structural redesign of the approach that makes me interested in it again.
Ok, I'm starting to get the point of this talk at this conf.
@leah I’m thinking web *sites* will get more javascript-heavy and interactive; the direction of web apps has long been going that way! :)
@marcato15 Though I've enjoyed all the talks, this is the talk I was most excited about. So much of the web is being built in javascript now, I find almost every new javascript framework exciting.
older version
@marcato15 I'm thinking of it more about future web app presentation layer building versus just about Spoutcore :)
I have been searching for a good guide, and have been unable to track one down.
@mkrisher the newer or older version?
Awesome, I wouldn't want to give up jQuery.
damn, I forgot about leafychat
Anyone got a recommendation for an IRC client for Windows? they all seem to suck.
@mileszs it's cool, powerful, fairly easy to get started with, but has a different philosophy than sproutcore, I think they are trying to keep backbone small (file size wise)
SproutCore.
@leah we're using backbone at Harvest some, but I would like us to reevaluate sproutcore for comparison
Um, does anyone else feel like this topic is just a long ad for sprout core . Not seeing why this is part of the conf
obviously, convore is pretty js heavy
@leah @mkrisher or BaseCamp.....or Google Wave or Plus.

So SproutCore is analogous/an alternative to jQuery or is it to be used in conjunction with jQuery? I noticed that Yehuda is also a jQuery core developer.
@alecgorge in conjunction with jQuery
@mkrisher agreed, I think the concepts are pretty important to the future of web apps... I'm thinking that web apps will be more javascript-heavy and interactive
@mkrisher thanks! it's one of the better use cases
I agree.
@mileszs ha!

you're not going to get me too riled up. I actually really like IRC

Convore is working really well from the web interface. I didn't even think to look for an app because this is working so well.
I wonder when autocorrect will stop trying to change "convore" every time I type it.
@mkrisher How do you like backbone?
@leah my mustache hasn't quite reach handlebar status
@leah convore is great for conferences by the way, much better than a twitter backchannel
@mileszs I was just messing with you, trying to start something since @leah was listening :)
@leah I can’t think of a web app I use these days that isn’t JS-heavy. Twitter, Flickr, Facebook, Convore, Teambox, etc. etc. etc.
It'll call an endpoint in your (server) app that supplies, say, JSON.
I need an iPad to use the Convore app :)
No! They each have their strengths, I think, and Convore is definitely shining in our current application of it.

Also, I'm a huge geek and you'll have to pry IRC away from six feet under ground.

This sounds like something I'll be playing with tomorrow. Very interesting.
Anyone know why views define their relationship to controllers and models in SC instead of vice versa?
@swilliams_et Yes, good luck to me!

So do SproutCore models then interface with MySQL on the backend somehow? How does the data move from the browser and to a real server and when exactly?
